conclusion: To determine how shadows A, B, C, and D change when the light source moves backward, consider principles of shadows and light.
When the light source moves backward, shadows generally become longer because the angle of light rays becomes more acute relative to the ground.
Shadows will maintain their direction relative to the light source and stretch further in the direction opposite to the light source.
The size of the shadow (in terms of width and height) may increase as the distance from the object to the ground increases, but this is more pronounced in the length.
As the light source moves backward, shadows will shift on the ground to extend further away from their respective objects.
Object A is a birdcage, and its shadow is labeled as A.
The shadow of the birdcage (A) will stretch further away from the birdcage, becoming longer while maintaining its shape.
Object B is a matchstick box, and its shadow is labeled as B.
The shadow of the matchstick box (B) will stretch longer, extending further from the box.
Object C is a funnel, and its shadow is labeled as C.
The shadow of the funnel (C) will elongate and may become more diffuse as the light source moves farther away.
Object D is a sword, and its shadow is labeled as D.
The shadow of the sword (D) will become longer, extending further away from the hilt.
As the light source moves backward, each shadow (A, B, C, D) will increase in length, shift further from the object, and maintain direction relative to the light source.
The shadows A, B, C, and D will become longer and extend further from their respective objects when the light source moves backward.
